metadata.title: The Effect of Mechanisation on Labour: Evidence from the Diffusion of Steam Power

relevance.topic: The effect of mechanisation on labour
relevance.relevance: The study is highly relevant as it examines the impact of steam power, a significant technological change, on labor displacement and employment outcomes in 19th-century France.

design.sample_characteristics: Industries in 19th-century France, focusing on steam-adopting and non-adopting industries.

dependent_variables.wage_changes: Wages grew significantly more among steam-adopting industries.

historical_context.institutional_context: No significant change in labor's share compared to non-adopters.

outcomes.main_findings: Wages and employment grew significantly more among steam-adopting industries compared to non-adopting peers. Growth in total revenue was also significantly higher among steam adopters.
outcomes.conclusions: The findings dispute the common view that industrial modernisation set labor back in absolute terms or relative to capitalists.

quality_assessment.methodological_limitations: Potential biases due to unobserved factors, addressed using IV strategy.
quality_assessment.coherence: The data consistently supports the conclusion that steam power adoption positively impacted wages and employment.
quality_assessment.adequacy_of_data: Rich historical data from two national industrial censuses in France.
quality_assessment.relevance: Highly relevant to understanding the impact of technological change on labor.
